issues.name: Check Engine Light
issues.description: The check engine light is illuminated, indicating a problem detected by the vehicle's computer system.

repair_options.name: Diagnostic Scan
repair_options.description: Use an OBD-II scanner to read the error codes from the vehicle's computer.
steps: Purchase or borrow an OBD-II scanner.
Locate the OBD-II port (usually under the dashboard near the steering column).
Connect the scanner and turn on the ignition.
Follow the scanner's instructions to read the error codes.
Look up the codes online or consult your vehicle's manual for their meaning.

repair_options.name: Professional Diagnosis
repair_options.description: Take your vehicle to a professional mechanic for diagnosis and repair.

safety_warnings: If the check engine light is flashing, reduce speed and seek immediate professional help.

issues.name: Fluid Leak
issues.description: Your vehicle appears to be leaking fluid, which could be oil, coolant, transmission fluid, brake fluid, or power steering fluid.

repair_options.name: Identify Fluid Type
repair_options.description: Determine what type of fluid is leaking by its color and consistency.
steps: Place a clean piece of cardboard under the leak overnight.
Check the color: red/pink (transmission/power steering), green/yellow (coolant), brown/black (oil), clear/brown (brake fluid).
Note the location of the leak (front, middle, or rear of vehicle).

repair_options.name: Check and Refill Fluid
repair_options.description: Check the fluid level and refill as necessary.
steps: Identify which fluid is low by checking all fluid reservoirs.
Purchase the correct type of fluid for your vehicle.
Refill the fluid to the proper level according to your owner's manual.

repair_options.name: Professional Leak Repair
repair_options.description: Have a mechanic identify and fix the source of the leak.

safety_warnings: Do not drive with low brake fluid; this is a serious safety hazard.
Do not drive with low oil pressure; this can cause catastrophic engine damage.
Do not drive an overheating vehicle (low coolant); this can cause severe engine damage.

issues.name: Brake Problem
issues.description: There may be an issue with your vehicle's braking system, which requires prompt attention for safety.

repair_options.name: Brake Pad Inspection
repair_options.description: Check the condition of your brake pads.
steps: Look through the wheel spokes at the brake rotor and caliper.
The brake pad should be visible against the rotor.
If the pad material is less than 1/4 inch thick, they need replacement.

repair_options.name: Brake Pad Replacement
repair_options.description: Replace worn brake pads before they damage the rotors.
steps: Purchase the correct brake pads for your vehicle.
Safely jack up your vehicle and remove the wheel.
Remove the caliper bolts and pivot the caliper away from the rotor.
Remove the old pads and replace with new ones.
Reinstall the caliper and wheel, then repeat for other wheels as needed.

repair_options.name: Professional Brake Service
repair_options.description: Have a professional mechanic inspect and repair your brake system.

safety_warnings: Brake issues are serious safety concerns and should be addressed immediately.
Do not drive with grinding brakes as this can lead to brake failure.
If your brake warning light is on, check your brake fluid level immediately.

issues.name: Battery Problem
issues.description: Your vehicle's battery or electrical system may be experiencing issues.

repair_options.name: Battery Inspection
repair_options.description: Check the battery terminals for corrosion and the battery charge level.
steps: Inspect battery terminals for white or greenish corrosion.
Clean terminals with a wire brush and baking soda solution if corroded.
Check battery age (usually printed on top).
If available, use a multimeter to check battery voltage (should be 12.6V when engine off).

repair_options.name: Battery Jump Start
repair_options.description: Jump start your vehicle if the battery is discharged.
steps: Position another vehicle close to yours, but not touching.
Turn off both vehicles.
Connect the red jumper cable to the positive terminal of your dead battery.
Connect the other end of the red cable to the positive terminal of the good battery.
Connect the black jumper cable to the negative terminal of the good battery.
Connect the other end of the black cable to a metal ground on your vehicle (not the negative battery terminal).
Start the working vehicle and let it run for a few minutes.
Try to start your vehicle. If successful, keep it running for at least 20 minutes.

repair_options.name: Battery Replacement
repair_options.description: Replace an old or failing battery.
steps: Purchase the correct battery for your vehicle.
Turn off the engine and all electrical components.
Disconnect the negative terminal first, then the positive.
Remove any battery hold-down clamps and carefully remove the old battery.
Install the new battery and secure it with hold-down clamps.
Connect the positive terminal first, then the negative.

repair_options.name: Professional Electrical System Diagnosis
repair_options.description: Have a mechanic check your vehicle's entire electrical system.

safety_warnings: Wear gloves and eye protection when working with batteries.
Never smoke or create sparks near a battery as they can release explosive gases.
Be careful not to touch the positive and negative terminals together with tools.

issues.name: Tire Problem
issues.description: One or more of your vehicle's tires may have issues with pressure, wear, or damage.

repair_options.name: Tire Pressure Check
repair_options.description: Check and adjust your tire pressure.
steps: Purchase a tire pressure gauge if you don't have one.
Check your vehicle's recommended tire pressure (usually on a sticker inside the driver's door).
Remove the valve cap from each tire and check the pressure when tires are cold.
Add air if the pressure is too low or release air if too high.
Replace the valve caps when finished.

repair_options.name: Tire Rotation
repair_options.description: Rotate your tires to ensure even wear.
steps: Safely jack up one corner of the vehicle and support it with a jack stand.
Remove the wheel and set it aside.
Repeat for the other wheels.
Rotate the tires according to the pattern in your owner's manual (typically front to back or cross pattern).
Reinstall all wheels and torque lug nuts to specification.

repair_options.name: Professional Tire Service
repair_options.description: Have a tire shop inspect, rotate, or replace your tires.

safety_warnings: Driving on severely worn or damaged tires is extremely dangerous.
Never drive on a tire with a visible bulge or with objects puncturing it.
Always maintain proper tire pressure for optimal safety and fuel economy.
